title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that law enforcement officers face increasing risks in the war against drugs and crime, with a rise in violent crime and drug use. A significant shift in challenges has not been met with adequate support from the Federal Government. Many individuals arrested test positive for drug usage. The Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965 highlighted various issues affecting law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, such as the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibilities, was recommended for evaluation. The Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965 identified key issues in law enforcement, such as drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and funding challenges. A reevaluation of the Federal Government's role in supporting officers, improving working conditions, and defining crime control responsibilities is crucial for reshaping relationships between the government, the public, and law enforcement officials. The "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" is established to address key issues in law enforcement identified by the Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice of 1965. This includes drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and funding challenges. The Commission's duties involve reevaluating the Federal Government's role in supporting officers, improving working conditions, and defining crime control responsibilities. The Commission will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, and research/training status. The Commission will study the status of law enforcement research, training, equipment, resources, cooperation among agencies, responsibility in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. The Commission will study the impact of the criminal justice system on law enforcement, including court schedules and prison overcrowding. They will conduct surveys and consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders to gather information and advice on important law enforcement issues. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including seven individuals from national law enforcement organizations appointed by various leaders in Congress and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members, including individuals appointed by leaders in Congress and the President. One individual representing a State or local governmental entity will be appointed by the President. The Comptroller General will oversee the methodology of the Commission's study, and members will select a chairperson. Members will not receive additional compensation for their service. Members of the Commission will not receive additional pay, allowance, or benefits for their service. They will, however, be reimbursed for travel expenses as per federal regulations. Appointments to the Commission must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested by the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and secure information from federal agencies to carry out its duties. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts and donations. The Commission has the authority to receive information from federal agencies, accept gifts and donations, and use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission will submit a report with legislative proposals to Congress within eighteen months of its appointment. It will cease to exist sixty days after submitting the report. The Commission will cease to exist sixty days after submitting its report to Congress. Additionally, certain titles from the Crime Control Act of 1990 and the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State Appropriations Act of 1991 will be repealed.
